hints_html:
What does it mean when a limit evaluates to a number? To infinity? Each limit listed above turns into a graph feature like a point or asymptote.

Each limit translates into the following graph feature:

  1. Approaching x = -1 from the left, the graph approaches the point (-1,0).

  2. There is a vertical asymptote at x = -1 and the function increases to \(\infty\) as it approaches x = -1 from the right.

  3. There is a vertical asymptote at x = 1 and the function decreases to \(-\infty\) as it approaches x = 1 from either side.
hints_latex:
What does it mean when a limit evaluates to a number? To infinity? Each
limit listed above turns into a graph feature like a point or asymptote.

Each limit translates into the following graph feature:

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Approaching \emph{x = -1} from the left, the graph approaches the
  point \emph{(-1,0)}.
\item
  There is a vertical asymptote at \emph{x = -1} and the function
  increases to $\infty$ as it approaches \emph{x = -1} from the right.
\item
  There is a vertical asymptote at \emph{x = 1} and the function
  decreases to $-\infty$ as it approaches \emph{x = 1} from either side.
\end{enumerate}
hints_raw:
What does it mean when a limit evaluates to a number?  To infinity?  Each limit listed above turns into a graph feature like a point or asymptote.
Each limit translates into the following graph feature: 

# Approaching ''x = -1'' from the left, the graph approaches the point ''(-1,0)''.
# There is a vertical asymptote at ''x = -1'' and the function increases to <math>\infty</math> as it approaches ''x = -1'' from the right.
# There is a vertical asymptote at ''x = 1'' and the function decreases to <math>-\infty</math> as it approaches ''x = 1'' from either side.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
See the second hint for how each limit translates into a feature of the graph.

  1. Your graph can do whatever it wants to the left of x = -1, so long as it approaches the point (-1,0). The simplest (yet somewhat boring) way to achieve this is by setting the function to 0 for x < -1.

  2. Between x = -1 and x = 1 the function has to fall from \(\infty\) to \(-\infty\).

  3. To the right of x = 1 the function has to come back from \(-\infty\) and then can do whatever you want it to do.

There is a lot of freedom in how your graph may look, but as long as you follow the key points above your graph will be correct. Below is our example (the purple lines represent asymptotes):
sols_latex:
See the second hint for how each limit translates into a feature of the
graph.

\begin{enumerate}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item
  Your graph can do whatever it wants to the left of \emph{x = -1}, so
  long as it approaches the point \emph{(-1,0)}. The simplest (yet
  somewhat boring) way to achieve this is by setting the function to
  \emph{0} for \emph{x \textless{} -1}.
\item
  Between \emph{x = -1} and \emph{x = 1} the function has to fall from
  $\infty$ to $-\infty$.
\item
  To the right of \emph{x = 1} the function has to come back from
  $-\infty$ and then can do whatever you want it to do.
\end{enumerate}

There is a lot of freedom in how your graph may look, but as long as you
follow the key points above your graph will be correct. Below is our
example \emph{(the purple lines represent asymptotes)}:

\begin{description}
\itemsep1pt\parskip0pt\parsep0pt
\item[]
\includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{../json_data/MATH110/April_2013/Math110_April2013_Question2b_solution.jpg}
\end{description}
sols_raw:
See the second hint for how each limit translates into a feature of the graph.

# Your graph can do whatever it wants to the left of ''x = -1'', so long as it approaches the point ''(-1,0)''. The simplest (yet somewhat boring) way to achieve this is by setting the function to ''0'' for ''x < -1''. 
# Between ''x = -1'' and ''x = 1'' the function has to fall from <math>\infty</math> to <math>-\infty</math>.
# To the right of ''x = 1'' the function has to come back from <math>-\infty</math> and then can do whatever you want it to do.

There is a lot of freedom in how your graph may look, but as long as you follow the key points above your graph will be correct. Below is our example ''(the purple lines represent asymptotes)'':

:[[File:Math110 April2013 Question2b solution.jpg|350px]]
statement_html:
Sketch a single function satisfying all of the listed criteria.

  1. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow -1^{-}} f(x) = 0\)

  2. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow -1^{+}} f(x) = \infty\)

  3. \(\lim_{x \rightarrow 1} f(x) = -\infty\)
statement_raw:
''Sketch a single function satisfying all of the listed criteria.''

# <math>\lim_{x \rightarrow -1^{-}} f(x) = 0 </math>
# <math>\lim_{x \rightarrow -1^{+}} f(x) = \infty </math>
# <math>\lim_{x \rightarrow 1} f(x) = -\infty </math>
